data.source: 2009 Afghanistan presidential election results at polling station level; ECC-ordered recount/visual inspection of ballot boxes; ECC formal complaints; WITS conflict/violence event data; 2007 NRVA household survey; GTOPO30 elevation data; LandScan population estimates; declassified military reports
data.wave_or_subset: Main analysis at district level for 398 districts during the 2009 presidential election; validation via random sample of 342 polling stations for recount; complaints data from 471 polling centers; NRVA 2007 survey covering 20,576 households across 383 districts; violence measured around the election period (election day and two months prior)
data.sample_size: 398 districts (main analysis); 342 polling stations (recount sample); 471 polling centers (complaints analysis); 20,576 households in NRVA (contextual controls)
data.unit_of_analysis: District (primary); polling station/center (for validation and complaints)
data.notes: Population data from LandScan due to absence of recent census; fraud measured using a last-digit test and validated with recount evidence; last-digit forensic approach may incur Type I/II errors; geographic controls include distance to Kabul and elevation.

method.description: The study measures electoral fraud in Afghanistan’s 2009 presidential election using a forensic last-digit test applied to polling-station results, validated against an ECC-ordered random recount of ballot boxes. District-level fraud measures are regressed on violence intensity (and its square) to test for an inverted U-shaped relationship, with controls for development and geography. Spatial models differentiate incumbent and challenger fraud responses to local and adjacent-district violence to test for static versus displaced fraud patterns.
steps: Assemble district-level election results aggregated from polling stations for the 2009 presidential election.
Compute forensic fraud indicators using the last-digit test (compare last-digit distributions to U(0,9)); derive district-level significance/p-values.
Validate fraud measures using ECC recount/visual inspection results from a random sample of 342 polling stations to estimate shares of manipulated boxes by district.
Construct violence measures (insurgent attacks per 1,000 population) using WITS for election day and the two months prior; compute adjacent-district violence where required.
Merge contextual controls: NRVA 2007 electrification share and per-capita expenditure; distance to Kabul; GTOPO30 elevation; LandScan population for per-capita scaling.
Estimate regressions of fraud measures on violence and violence squared (logit for last-digit significance; OLS for recount-based fraud share), including controls.
Estimate candidate-specific models (incumbent vs. challenger) including adjacent-district violence and election logistics (e.g., closed polling stations) to assess spatial displacement.
Conduct robustness checks across alternative datasets/measures and time windows.
method.models: Logit regression for last-digit test fraud indicator; OLS regression for recount-based fraud share; candidate-specific OLS models including adjacent-district violence and controls.
method.outcome_variable: Measures of electoral fraud: (a) last-digit test indicator/p-value by district; (b) estimated share of manipulated ballot boxes from recount at district level; candidate-specific fraud indicators.
method.independent_variables: Violence intensity (insurgent attacks per 1,000 population) on election day and in the two months preceding; squared violence term; adjacent-district violence; number of closed polling stations.
method.control_variables: Electrification (NRVA 2007); per-capita expenditure (NRVA 2007); distance to Kabul; elevation (GTOPO30); population (LandScan) for per-capita scaling.

results.summary: Fraud is most prevalent at moderate levels of violence and declines in highly violent areas, supporting an inverted U-shaped relationship between violence and fraud. Validation shows a positive correlation between last-digit forensic flags and recount-based evidence of manipulation. Incumbent-linked networks exhibit static fraud with no spatial displacement, whereas challenger-linked fraud responds to adjacent violence, consistent with mobile strategies. Several covariates, including the number of closed polling stations and electrification, significantly relate to measured fraud.
